Base.name: ADD/ADHD
Base.description1: a chronic difference that includes very high energy levels, difficulty maintaining attention, and impulsivity
Base.description2: people with ADD/ADHD are often more creative and spontaneous than their peers
Base.description3: those with ADD/ADHD may have difficulty following instructions and organizing tasks or activities

Base.name: Dyslexia
Base.description1: people with dyslexia are often unusually spatially aware and creative, and make compelling public speakers
Base.description2: signs of dyslexia include trouble reading, writing, and spelling
Base.description3: people with dyslexia may experience difficulty learning foreign languages and have poor handwriting

Base.name: Dyscalculia
Base.description1: those with dyscalculia may have trouble reading analog clocks, working with budgets and timelines, performing basic math skills, and differentiating between numbers and values
Base.description2: struggling with algebraic matrices or flunking calculus don't necessarily suggest dyscalculia, which complicates basic math functions like simple addition
Base.description3: people with dyscalculia are often highly strategic and intuitive thinkers, have advanced language skills, and can approach problem-solving with creative and practical verve

Base.name: Dysgraphia
Base.description1: dysgraphia affects children and adults, and interferes with most writing processes including spelling, legibility, word spacing and sizing, and expression
Base.description2: people with dysgraphia have trouble forming letter shapes and may have a tight, awkward, or painful grip on pen or pencil; they often thrive with keyboarding and computer programs supporting editing and reorganization
Base.description3: advanced listening, story-telling, and memorization skills can make those with dysgraphia notably more comfortable and engaging in social contexts than their peers

Base.name: Deafness
Base.description1: The World Health Organization estimates that over 1 billion young adults are at risk of permanent, avoidable hearing loss from unsafe listening practices
Base.description2: people with hearing loss or who are 'hard of hearing' usually communicate with spoken language; 'deaf' people have very little or no hearing and often sign to communicate
Base.description3: SL emerged as a language in the American School for the Deaf, founded in 1817; it brought together Old French Sign Language, various village sign languages, and home sign systems

Base.name: Tourette’s Syndrome
Base.description1: a nervous system condition that causes the individual to make involuntary sounds and movements called ‘tics’
Base.description2: some people with Tourette’s have a gift for hyper-focusing, exhibit greater cognitive control over other motor impulses, and benefit from increased humour and creativity
Base.description3: Tourette’s is characterized by multiple motor tics and at least one vocal (phonic) tic

Base.name: Sleep Apnea
Base.description1: sleep apnea causes breathing pauses or shallow breathing during sleep, as well as loud snoring
Base.description2: this common and often chronic condition disrupts deep sleep and can make people tired during the day
Base.description3: many treatments are available for sleep apnea, like OTC sleeping pills or sinus medication for mild cases; CPAP machines can help clear airways to reduce sleep apnea disruptions

Base.name: Amputee
Base.description1: an amputee is someone who has partially or entirely lost one or more limbs
Base.description2: reasons for amputation can include severe injuries, cancerous tumours, acute infections, thickening of nerve tissue, and frostbite
Base.description3: amputees can use artificial limbs and assistive devices to live fully without missing limb(s), including creating new artistic forms and learning opportunities for and with other amputees

Base.name: Hyperthymesia
Base.description1: the condition of possessing an extremely detailed autobiographical memory of a vast number of life experiences
Base.description2: people with hyperthymesia spend large amounts of time thinking about their pasts and may recall almost every day of their lives in near perfect detail
Base.description3: minute access to their past can help people boost their mood by accessing happy memories, keep them from repeating mistakes, and nurture compassion and forgiveness for others

Base.name: Anxiety
Base.description1: if not too intense, anxiety can improve performance and conscientiousness, increase empathy, alert people to danger, and help people work or study more sustainably
Base.description2: most people experience anxiety at some point but it can become a disorder, of which generalized anxiety disorder is the most common
Base.description3: anxiety is experienced widely, for many reasons; it can manifest as fatigue, lack of focus, panic attacks, sleeping trouble, and GI issues

Base.name: Down Syndrome
Base.description1: a congenital difference including lower than average intellectual capacity and physical variations like short stature and broad facial profile
Base.description2: Down syndrome babies now have a life expectancy (in the west) of 50-60 years and Downs adults are building careers in various artistic sectors like acting and modelling
Base.description3: people with Down syndrome are often more nurturing and have greater well-being than their non-Down syndrome peers

Base.name: Dwarfism
Base.description1: a condition that causes slow growth, affecting individuals’ heights and resulting in short stature
Base.description2: the terms 'dwarf', 'little person', 'LP', and 'person of short stature' are now generally considered acceptable by most people affected by this condition
Base.description3: people with dwarfism often struggle with social prejudice due to their height, as well as difficulties in day-to-day tasks such as driving

Base.name: Arthritis
Base.description1: painful inflammation and stiffness of the joints that becomes more common with age
Base.description2: arthritis can decrease one’s range of motion, making it difficult to complete daily tasks
Base.description3: symptoms may be alleviated with low-impact exercise like swimming and healthy diet, as both increase general well-being

Base.name: Narcolepsy
Base.description1: narcoleptics can often sleep anywhere and anytime, resulting in effective power naps and minimal jet lag from long-distance travel
Base.description2: people with narcolepsy may feel drowsy and excessive daytime fatigue, and fall asleep at undesirable times
Base.description3: those with this difference experience disturbed sleep routines which can negatively impact daily activities like work or school but may help them more easily adapt to shift work (as in hospitals)

Base.name: Epilepsy
Base.description1: epilepsy is abnormal brain cell activity resulting in unprovoked seizures
Base.description2: this condition can lead to non-pharmacological euphoria and significantly increased creativity
Base.description3: symptoms may include temporary confusion, staring spells, unintentional jerking movements, and loss of consciousness or awareness

Base.name: Blindness
Base.description1: the condition of poor visual perception or complete vision loss
Base.description2: blind persons often find their other senses are much more finely honed than their fully sighted peers’ senses
Base.description3: people with this difference may use various tools to enhance daily life, such as guide dogs, canes, and smartphones

Base.name: Depression
Base.description1: depression disrupts a person’s daily functional abilities but seems often to correlate to intellectual and creative genius
Base.description2: depression can induce people to be overly critical and they may seem incapable of having fun
Base.description3: people with depression can feel hopeless, sad, irritable, and lack energy and self-esteem

Base.name: Amnesia
Base.description1: amnesia is whole or partial memory loss resulting from injury, illness, or other causes
Base.description2: people with this difference can learn new information but may not remember the act of learning new information
Base.description3: memory loss ranges from specific inputs and facts, to an inability to transfer information into long-term memory

Base.name: Anosmia
Base.description1: anosmia is the complete absence of the sense of smell and may be either temporary or permanent
Base.description2: it may not prevent one from becoming a global ice cream magnate—both Ben and Jerry reportedly have anosmia
Base.description3: it can affect appetite, smell memory, and libido

Base.name: Autism
Base.description1: people with autism have a range of intelligence levels but many test well above average
Base.description2: autistic people often have a particularly keen interest in specific items or information, with a matching ability to focus
Base.description3: people with autism sometimes react strongly to stimuli

Base.name: Ageusia
Base.description1: ageusia is the inability to detect tastes, such as sweetness, sourness, bitterness, saltiness, and umami
Base.description2: this loss of taste can be caused by neurological damage, endocrine system problems, tobacco use, and aging—some simple lifestyle changes may revive the ability to taste
Base.description3: the tongue can only sense texture and tastes, so most of what is perceived as taste is derived from smell

Base.name: Synesthesia
Base.description1: a crossing of neurological pathways where stimuli that usually affect one sense involuntarily and simultaneously trigger another; synesthetes may get exhausted from sensory overload
Base.description2: a common form of synesthesia causes individuals to perceive numbers and letters as intrinsically coloured
Base.description3: it may confer sensory enhancements, such as making synesthetes better able to distinguish between smells and between colours; most seem to enjoy their amplified and elegantly combined senses
